node.text: Almost 30 years ago, an American court ruled that victims of the Ferdinand Marcos regime in the Philippines should be compensated — setting off one of the most ambitious and valuable treasure hunts of all time. (via @businessweek)

node.title: Where Did Marcos Hide His $10 Billion Fortune?

node.text: An anonymous donor turned a tiny Pacific coast town without a bank into the world's biggest Bitcoin experiment. Here's how life has changed on El Savaldor's Bitcoin beach. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Bitcoin Beach: The Surf Town That Went Crypto

node.text: Airbnb's $100 billion business model is built on strangers trusting each other. When things go horribly wrong, the company's secretive safety team steps in to soothe guests and hosts, help families and prevent PR disasters. (via @businessweek)

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text: The sudden cancellation of Ant Group’s IPO shocked investors, but Beijing's slapdown of Jack Ma was years in the making. And Alibaba and Ant aren't the only tech firms under scrutiny by Chinese regulators.

node.title: How China Lost Patience With Its Loudest Billionaire

node.text:
Plant-based meat used to mean burgers and sausages. Not anymore.

Using techniques from 3D printing to specially cultivated mushrooms, these companies are at the forefront of the next generation of alternative meats: whole cuts. (via @quicktake)

Tap the link in bio for more pictures. (via @quicktake)

node.text:
Taiwan is becoming a bigger issue between the world's two biggest superpowers. Taipei — a U.S. ally — and Beijing have avoided war for more than seven decades, but that balance is getting harder to maintain as China becomes more assertive in its desire for reunification.

Watch the full video at the link in bio to understand why analysts say Taiwan's status is "the most likely issue to draw China and the U.S. into a direct military conflict."

node.title: Why the Biggest U.S.-China Issue Is About Taiwan

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 08, 2021. May be an image of ocean and text that says 'Hawaii's housing marketis booming with work-f -from- anywhere buyers Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Hawaii’s real estate sales have been through a big couple of weeks.

An eight-bedroom oceanfront mansion in Maui recently changed hands for $45 million, Hawaii’s second-most expensive home on record. Days earlier, Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen’s estate on the Big Island sold for $43 million, while a home in the beachfront neighborhood of Lanikai went for $24 million just a week before that. 

The sales reflect a hot Hawaii real estate market fueled by a pandemic that has made the islands a desirable place to isolate and work remotely — and it’s not just multimillion-dollar homes that are affected. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Elon Muskis doing something that's fairly rare these days: building stuff BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
A lot of the hype surrounding Tesla derives from hopelessly online people cheering on one of their own, Elon Musk. But @bloombergopinion columnists also believe some of it might also have to do with the fact that Musk and Tesla are doing something relatively rare in today’s economy: building stuff.

For the past 40 years or so, the U.S. economy has been a consuming machine. Occasionally we do invent, say, Facebook or the iPhone, but then we mostly use those to consume more stuff, explains Mark Gongloff.

Now the U.S. economy has a chance to get back on the right track, one aimed more at building future wealth than living on past glories.

Harnessing and domesticating some of that Tesla buzz could be the key. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 08, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'turns Itturnsoutbigcitylifeisn't out big city life isn't making you depressed 33 PT Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Cities have long battled a poor reputation as cauldrons of stress, fostering high rates of depression and other mental illnesses. But new research suggests that big cities actually have some mental health benefits over their smaller counterparts.

The study draws on mathematical models and multiple datasets to try to gauge how city size and the “built environment,’’ like structures and roads, influence depression.

It turns out that the casual social interactions that big cities force upon us help buffer against mental health strain. Smaller cities, with less hubbub, may not offer as many benefits in fighting depression. Tap the link in bio to read more about the study, via @citylab.

📷: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake/AFP via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, car and text that says 'China's China'sinfluencersare influencers now pitching electric cars BALENCIAGA CIAGA Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Emma Meng, or EV Emma as she’s known to her 700,000 followers, is among the swelling ranks of Chinese influencers blogging and vlogging cars in the world’s biggest electric vehicle market.

The money is so good that some like Meng, who worked as a regional business developer in France, were able to ditch their corporate careers.

In the process, they’re helping reshape the way automobiles are sold in a nation that was late to embrace personal car ownership but is driving full speed into cleaner, greener vehicles. Tap the link in bio to read more. (via @businessweek)

📷: Photo from Emma Meng

node.text: Almost 30 years ago, an American court ruled that victims of the Ferdinand Marcos regime in the Philippines should be compensated — setting off one of the most ambitious and valuable treasure hunts of all time. (via @businessweek)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 07, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text.

node.text:
FinTwit isn't new. But in 2021, its stars have become required reading for anyone wanting to understand the markets.

Some, like Lily Francus, are on Twitter to share academic insight. The 25-year-old created her account less than a year ago; her NOPE model, which helped explain feedback loops behind the GameStop phenomenon, has won her thousands of followers.

Others, like L.A.-based Kyla Scanlon, have become internet famous by combining market insights and comedy in tweets, TikTok videos and Substack newsletters.

What started as a loose community is helping young people in finance find an audience for their ideas, as well as memes. Tap the link in our bio for the ones to watch. (via @businessweek)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, laptop, office and text that says 'One-mancrypto crypto outfits are rushing forrichesbefore before Wall Street invades Bloon Blo Wealth'.

node.text:
Matthew Tweed is worlds apart from Wall Street traders.
 
The 20-year-old never went to college and works out of his bedroom at the family home in Surrey, England. Yet thanks to the fragmented world of crypto, Tweed is making markets in Bitcoin derivatives with his one-man operation — using skills he learned on Reddit.

His ambitions would be nigh impossible in highly regulated and liquid markets like stocks, where deep-pocketed pros ramp up the barriers for entry for the little guys. But where there’s money to be made, Wall Street is sure to follow. Read in full at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Virgin's ticketto space now costs nearly half a million dollars Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Inflation isn’t just climbing here on Earth. Virgin Galactic is resuming ticket sales for trips to space at a new price of $450,000 a ride.

Sales are restarting immediately and available tickets range from individual seats to a “full-flight buyout,” CEO Michael Colglazier said. Virgin Galactic had charged $250,000 for each ticket before halting sales while it continued work on its spacecraft. Tap the link in bio to read more.

📷: Susan Montoya Bryan/AP Photo

node.text: An anonymous donor turned a tiny Pacific coast town without a bank into the world's biggest Bitcoin experiment. Here's how life has changed on El Savaldor's Bitcoin beach. (via @quicktake)

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 06, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'UNITED UNITEDA ORD United becomes first major U.S. airline to require worker vaccination Bloomberg'.

node.text:
United Airlines said workers must get vaccinated against the coronavirus, becoming the first major U.S. carrier to impose the mandate.

Employees must receive the vaccine and upload their injection record to a company database no later than Oct. 25, although that date could change, United said in a memo Friday. 

United joins a growing list of companies prompted by the delta variant to require proof of vaccination from employees, from Facebook to Tyson Foods. Tap the link in our bio for the full story.

📷: Scott Olson/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 06, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing, indoor and text that says 'Breakfast Breakfastandice-cream: and Firms ramp up food perks to coax workers back Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Goldman Sachs believes the way to a banker's heart is a free meal. As companies grapple with how to encourage staff back to their buildings, others are following suit.
 
Free breakfast, lunch and ice-cream are part of Goldman's pitch to convince U.K. employees to leave the comfort of their homes. Advertising firm Havas is investing in its in-house kitchen and cafe, inviting employees to make menu suggestions. Others, like asset manager Janus Henderson, have switched from subsidized meals to freebies.

Does management by food actually work? Tap the link in our bio for more on who's serving what.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 06, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Ether touched a two-month high this week after an upgrade to its underlying network, the latest boost during a stellar run for Bitcoin’s biggest rival.

Its gains for the year now stand at about 280%, well ahead of Bitcoin’s 40% advance in the same period — which includes a tumble from a record of almost $65,000 in April.

Changes to the way Ether is managed took effect on Thursday, including a fee reduction feature and tweaks its inventor says will lead to a 99% reduction in energy use. Tap the link in our bio to read more.
